text:
AMY GALLO: What's
the first thing that

comes to mind when I
say workplace gossip?

Do alarm bells go
off in your mind?

Danger, danger--
avoid at all costs.
Do you feel intrigued?

Ooh, what's the
latest juicy rumor?
Maybe a bit of both--

hmm, I'm tempted, but
I know I shouldn't.
Guess what.
You're not alone.

Many people feel conflicted
about the role of gossip
in the workplace.

The truth is that
everyone participates

in some form of
workplace gossip,

whether it's positive,
neutral, or negative.

It can be a natural way
to connect with others,

learn about ourselves,
glean important information,

and process what's
going on around us.
And here's the reality.
Not all gossip is created equal.

Some forms of
gossip are actually

beneficial to a
healthy workplace,

while others can be very
harmful to people, teams,
and organizations.

In this video, I'm
going to destigmatize

the good kind of gossip and
give you some rules of thumb

to help you figure out when it's
OK and not OK to gossip at work.
[UPBEAT MUSIC]
Let's start with the definition.

Put simply, gossip is
informal, talk about someone
when that person is not present.

For example, let's say Kai and
Jesse are talking about Adrian,
who's not in the room.

It's easy to assume that it's
a bad idea for them to engage

in gossip because
their words could hurt

Adrian's feelings or worse,
damage Adrian's reputation
and future success at work.

And that is something
they should avoid.

We'll come back to
that in a moment.

But first, let's explore the
ways in which their gossip could
be a good thing--
gossip as general information.

What if we used the word
information instead of gossip.

That changes how
we see it, right?

Here are some scenarios where
general information-gathering
gossip is beneficial.

Maybe Kai and Jesse are
trying to figure out

how Adrian's group landed
a big contract because they

can't get any answers from
top leadership about it.

Or perhaps Kai's
intention was trying

to interpret a strangely-worded
email from Adrian.

It could be helpful to
get Jesse's impression
before responding to Adrian.

Or perhaps Jesse knows it's
crucial to get Adrian's support

in order to move a
stalled project forward,

and Kai might have some insight
or advice on how to do that.

These are all situations where
Kai and Jesse are gossiping

to gather information
that will help process
what's going on around them.

This probably isn't
what you immediately

think of when you
hear the word gossip.

More likely, you
think of the chatter

that includes
reputational information

or judgments of a person's
abilities or experiences.

Gossip as reputational
information.

I want to point out that this
kind of reputational gossip
can be positive.

Jesse could be praising
Adrian to Kai, pointing out

that they've done excellent
work or provided extra help
on a project.

This positive gossip is
good information to share.

Fun fact-- research has shown
that positive gossip is actually

more common than
negative gossip.

Or perhaps Kai is
Adrian's manager.
Yes, managers gossip, too.

And it's helpful
to know from Jesse

that some employees are having
issues working with Adrian.

In the role of
manager, Kai could then

use this reputational
information

as diagnostic feedback to
help Adrian work better
with their colleagues.

It's important to note that
while negative gossip can

undermine an organization's
ability to function,

it can also serve as a
valuable red flag about larger
organizational issues.

If you're a manager,
my advice is this.
Don't try to ban gossip.

It's more constructive
to address

the problems that are
generating the negative talk
in the first place.

Another benefit
to gossip is this.

It can help co-workers
form connections
and establish workplace norms.

Let's say Kai and
Jesse were engaging

in some negative gossip,
like commiserating

about Adrian's passive
aggressive communication style.

Even if their talk
isn't particularly kind,

the two colleagues are forming
their own personal bond,

learning that they
can trust each other

to vent their feelings
and share honest opinions.

This social and
emotional support

can make Kai and Jesse feel
more connected to each other

and to the organization
as a whole.

They may experience
reduced workplace anxiety

and also get to enjoy
the. natural adrenaline

and dopamine rush that
happens to all of us

when we get confirmation that
we are right about something.

And when Max from accounting
joins the conversation

and agrees, they start to form
a larger ingroup with a shared
opinion about Adrian.

I know, while this in-group
may sound like a middle school

clique, out of which
nothing good can come,

it can actually accomplish
something beyond group bonding.

Research has shown that it
can actually deter Kai, Jesse,

and Max from
behaving like Adrian,

in part because
they know they might

be ostracized or indirectly
punished if they do.

Their behavior is improved
and likely rewarded.

And this can spread, prompting
others to follow suit.

In other words, gossip can
establish and reinforce

norms about what is acceptable
behavior in a workplace.

You can see how even
managers might approve

of this kind of gossip because
it can reinforce company values,

disincentivize poor behavior,
and encourage all employees
to do their best work.
But this is important.

Talking behind a
coworker's back,

even if it has benefits for
others, does have drawbacks.

And we don't want to forget
the potential consequences

to Adrian's reputation and
possibly their well-being.

So let's talk
about the pitfalls.

Of course, gossip isn't
always a good thing,

and it comes with risks beyond
hurt feelings and tarnished
reputations.

Gossip can decrease
productivity by taking up

valuable time, yours and that
of the people around you.

This time suck isn't just
about the minutes or hours

that you spend talking
instead of working.

It's also about the time that
it takes people to figure out

whether the gossip is
helpful or real, which
leads to another pitfall.

Gossip can spread
misinformation,

which can generate fear
and cause a lot of damage.

Gossip can also make people
susceptible to what's
known as confirmation bias.

While Kai feels good when Jesse
agrees that Adrian is passive

aggressive, their commiseration
makes it more likely for Kai

to see everything Adrian
does through that lens.

Even if Adrian only
occasionally behaves poorly,

the "Adrian is
passive aggressive"

narrative becomes a
self-fulfilling prophecy,

and it becomes harder and
harder for Kai, Jesse, Max,

and everyone else to see
Adrian's behavior as anything
other than passive aggressive.

Also, and this is
critical to remember,

gossip often reflects
poorly on the gossiper.

If Jesse relentlessly
criticizes Adrian to Kai,

Jesse runs the risk of
being seen as untrustworthy.

Kai might wonder, is Jesse
criticizing me behind my back,
too?

This erosion of
trust can snowball

into hurt feelings, lower
morale, damaged reputations,

divisiveness, and
staff attrition.

It's not just Kai and Jesse's
relationship that suffers,

but the team or organizational
culture can suffer as well.
Not good.

So how do you avoid
these pitfalls?
Proceed with caution.

Some important
rules of thumb focus

on sharing positive
or neutral gossip.

It's inevitable that
we'll occasionally

talk about our coworkers
when they're not around.

When you do, ask yourself,
if my coworker knew

what I was saying about
them, how would they feel?

Next, only share gossip
with colleagues you trust.

You want to feel confident that
they won't reveal what you've

said to others,
especially those who

might see your gossiping
in an unfavorable light.

Be careful about
where and how you
share information in private.

Behind closed doors is a better
bet than in a public area.

And definitely avoid
gossiping and writing,

like over email or text,
which you should always assume
can be made public at any time.

Author Deborah Grayson Riegel
has some additional strategies.

She suggests pivoting to
a more constructive line
of conversation.

If someone comes
to you with gossip,

resist the temptation to
engage in negative talk.

Instead, pivot the conversation
by asking something

like, how can I help you
achieve a better outcome?

This redirection can ensure
you and your colleague

are engaging in
coaching, brainstorming,

or problem solving, not just
confirming existing problems.

If you're tempted to
gossip, ask yourself,

why do I need confirmation
from one person
about someone else's behavior?

What is my goal in
talking about this?

If your answer is just to
validate your own opinions

or feelings, don't drag someone
else into the conversation,
even if it might feel good.

However, if their
confirmation provides insight

into how you might be
contributing to the problem

or gives you ways to brainstorm
constructive solutions

or helps you go on record
with a formal complaint,
then go for it.

Create a feedback-rich
environment around you.

When you normalize
giving and receiving

direct feedback, both
positive and negative,

there will be less
temptation to gossip.

One way to do this is to let
people know you have a policy.

If you have a problem with
me, please tell me first.

If people know you can
handle all kinds of feedback

with a good attitude
and without retaliating,

this will not only discourage
others from talking about you

when you're not
around, but encourages

them to be open to
direct feedback as well.

When a colleague is approached
with gossip about someone else,

you want the norm to
be for them to ask,
have you already told them?

It can also become
standard practice

to have feedback as
part of regular meetings

rather than saving it
all for, say, once a year
performance reviews.

Of course, if the
gossip crosses the line

into something that
could harm someone's

feelings or reputation, you
should nip that in the bud.

You could say something like, I
worry that's hurtful to Adrian

or I don't see why any of
us here needs to know that.

Or even counteract it by
mentioning positive experiences
you've had with that person.

That said, in a workplace where
honest feedback is the norm,

people will be more likely
to solve interpersonal issues
constructively.
Thanks for watching.

All of these strategies
are based on articles
linked in the description.

Do you have any advice on
gossip in the workplace,

or do you have any other big
topics you'd like me to cover?
Comment below.
Bye for now.
